intro: Amphipogon strictus var. avenaceus, commonly known as the narrowleaf sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family, characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and showy, clustered inflorescences. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and pale green to yellowish in color. This variety is noted for its drought tolerance and ability to stabilize sandy soils, making it an important plant in ecological restoration efforts.
